author: Leicester Mercury
title: Leicester Mercury published BUSINESS COMMENT "These are strange times indeed"
text:
Comments (0) 
The shock of the Brexit vote and the election of Donald Trump as US President contributed to a turbulent 2016. So what seismic events can we expect in 2017 and how will local businesses cope? 
Recently, we've seen the pound fall to a 31-year low, the FTSE 100 reach a record high, interest rates cut to historic lows and oil prices start to rise. 
Meanwhile, huge question marks hang over the UK's future trading relationships with our European and global partners. 
These are strange times indeed. 
With uncertain outcomes in the general elections planned in the Netherlands, France and Germany, and continuing concerns around the fragility of the Italian banks in particular, 2017 could serve up yet further shocks. 
So how are local businesses reacting? In truth, with great resilience. 
I've detected a real change in approach in recent months. 
"Even the Bank of England said the economy performed well" 
Shocks to the system are becoming the norm but rather than going into meltdown, business people I speak to are remarkably sanguine. 
Why is this? One of the reasons is the experience of the financial crash. 
Those businesses who survived the great recession and the consequent credit crunch are leaner and meaner than before. 
Many believe that if they can survive that they can survive anything. 
Second, they understand that in this strange transition period, business confidence will, in the words of the Chancellor, be on a "rollercoaster". 
Business people accept this and are focused on what they can influence, rather than what they can't. 
Finally, despite the worst fears of some economists, the UK economy has performed well since the referendum. 
Employment is strong, house prices are holding up and key surveys indicate that the construction, manufacturing and services sectors are in rude health. 
Consumers are also feeling confident enough about their future prospects to keep spending.
